Explanation: The doctor effectively gathered relevant information about the patient's abdominal pain by asking about its onset, characteristics, severity, associated symptoms, and duration.
The doctor specifically asked the patient when they first noticed the abdominal pain, which directly relates to the onset of the symptoms.
The doctor did not specifically ask about the location of the abdominal pain, which is crucial to determine if it is in the lower right side of the abdomen.
The doctor successfully asked the patient to rate their abdominal pain on a scale of 1 to 10, which directly corresponds to the patient's reported severity of 6 out of 10.
The doctor specifically asked the patient to describe the pain, which allowed the patient to provide the details of it being sharp and cramping.
The doctor did not ask any questions regarding the radiation of the abdominal pain, which is essential to determine if the pain is localized or if it radiates to other areas.
The doctor did not inquire about any alleviating or exacerbating factors related to the patient's abdominal pain.
The doctor specifically asked about other symptoms associated with the abdominal pain, which led to the patient mentioning nausea and mild fever.
The doctor specifically asked about changes in bowel habits, which led to the patient revealing their constipation.
The doctor specifically asked about changes in appetite, which led to the patient reporting a decreased appetite.
The doctor did not inquire about any previous episodes of similar abdominal pain, which is essential to determine the patient's history regarding this condition.
The doctor specifically asked about current medications, which included over-the-counter drugs, allowing the patient to disclose their occasional use of ibuprofen.
The doctor specifically asked about chronic medical conditions, which allowed the patient to disclose their hypertension and its management.
The doctor specifically asked about any recent illnesses, injuries, or surgeries, which allowed the patient to disclose their appendectomy at age 20.
The doctor specifically asked about the family medical history, which led to the patient providing information about her mother's diabetes and father's hypertension.
The doctor did not ask any questions related to the patient's occupation, which is necessary to gather a complete medical history.
The doctor specifically asked about alcohol use, which allowed the patient to provide the relevant information about their drinking habits.
The doctor did not specifically ask about the use of illicit drugs, which is necessary to determine if the patient has ever used them.
The doctor explicitly asked about the patient's smoking history, which allowed the patient to confirm that they have never smoked.
The doctor specifically asked about the patient's lifestyle, including exercise habits, which led to the patient revealing that they walk three times a week.
The doctor specifically asked about the patient's lifestyle, including diet, which led to the patient providing information about their balanced diet and occasional fast food consumption.
The doctor specifically asked about allergies to medications, which led to the patient disclosing their allergy to penicillin.
